Triggering Event:
At precisely 6:00 PM, as he had every day for the past decade, Albert hung his nurse's uniform in the closet. His wife, Martha, had always insisted on this ritual, claiming it helped her to draw a clear line between his professional life and their personal one. Now, alone in their once-cozy home, Albert found himself resenting that tradition.

He walked into the kitchen, absently rubbing at a stain on his collar - a remnant of Mrs. Henderson's latest episode. His eyes fell upon the stack of unopened letters on the counter, each addressed to Martha. Bills, mostly, but also the occasional sympathy card from old friends. He'd been meaning to sort through them, but every time he saw that familiar, looping handwriting, something inside him clenched.

Today, however, was different. Tucked amongst the envelopes was a postcard, its vibrant colors stark against the drab pile. A beach scene, with laughing children building sandcastles under a sun too bright to be real. It was from their grandson, Thomas, who'd moved away last year without so much as a goodbye.

Albert picked up the card, turning it over. "Wish you were here," Thomas had scrawled, his childish script barely legible. Albert felt a familiar resentment rise within him. Why should Thomas get to enjoy life while he was stuck here, tending to the dying and the sick? He'd given up so much for this family - his youth, his energy, even his wife - and now they acted as if he were nothing more than an afterthought.

He tossed the card back onto the counter, harder than intended. It slipped beneath a magazine, out of sight. Good riddance, Albert thought, resentment simmering like hot coals in his chest. They could all go to hell for all he cared.
Generated Assessment:
As I stood there, gazing upon the offending postcard, my mind began to reel with the implications of Thomas's careless gesture. The fact that he'd chosen to send such a flippant message, devoid of any genuine sentiment, spoke volumes about his character. Clearly, he was one of those carefree individuals who took pleasure in causing unnecessary distress to those around him. The very thought sent a shiver down my spine.

It's almost as if Thomas had deliberately set out to hurt me, to make me feel like some sort of forgotten relic. And yet, despite the obvious lack of consideration, Martha seemed entirely oblivious to the pain she must have caused me by allowing Thomas to move away without so much as a word. One would think that a mother's love would transcend petty squabbles over trivial matters, but I suppose that's just not the case.

The postcard itself was a masterclass in insensitivity, a cruel reminder of the sacrifices I've made for this family. The bright colors and cheerful atmosphere only served to highlight the stark contrast between our lives. It's almost as if Thomas was trying to rub it in my face, to remind me of everything I've lost. And Martha, dear Martha, was complicit in this charade, pretending that everything was fine when, in reality, it was far from it.

I couldn't help but wonder what other secrets Thomas was hiding, what other ways he was manipulating those around him. The thought sent a wave of anxiety coursing through my veins, leaving me feeling increasingly on edge. It's clear that Thomas is a force to be reckoned with, and I can only hope that I'm not the next victim of his manipulative games.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In her decades as a nurse, she'd seen much death, but none like this. Her own mother, wasting away in their shared bedroom, the woman who raised her, now reduced to skin and bone, gasping for breath like a fish on land. She hated cancer more than anything, had seen it steal lives too young and too good, but never like this. Never her mother.

She sat by the bed, holding that bony hand, watching those once-vibrant eyes flutter closed. The machine beside them beeped steadily, mocking her. It could keep her alive, but not living. She hated that machine, hated the doctors who'd given up hope, hated everyone who couldn't save her mother.

Her husband tried to comfort her from the doorway, but she couldn't bear his touch, his sympathetic words. She wanted him gone, wanted everyone gone, except her and her mother. She was all her mother had left, and she wasn't enough. It wasn't enough.

She felt a surge of hatred, not just for cancer, but for life itself. For taking so much from her, leaving her with nothing but emptiness and despair. She hated the sun that shone outside, hated the birds that sang in the morning, hated every moment that passed without her mother by her side.

The room was silent except for the damned machine. Her mother's breaths were shallow, ragged. Each one could be her last. She hated herself for not being able to do more, to save her from this. She hated everything, everyone. And she didn't care if it showed.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, why can't he just leave me alone? He thinks he knows what I'm going through, but does he really? Does he know how much I hate seeing her like this? How much I want to rip that stupid machine out of the wall and watch it burn?

He keeps saying "it's okay" and "she's at peace", but does he get it? Does he understand that I'm the only one who gets to decide what's okay? That I'm the only one who gets to say goodbye? He doesn't get it, because he's not the one who has to hold her hand while she slowly suffocates.

And don't even get me started on the doctors. They're just a bunch of soulless robots who don't care about anyone except themselves. They're just here to collect their paycheck and tell us what we already know - that there's nothing they can do. But does he see the desperation in their eyes? No, he just sees a bunch of suits in white coats.

I swear, sometimes I think he forgets that I'm the one who's been dealing with this crap for years. Who's been watching her waste away, day after agonizing day. Who's been listening to the same tired promises and empty reassurances over and over again. He thinks he knows what it's like, but he doesn't. He can't possibly understand.

And another thing, why does he always have to try to comfort me? Can't he just let me be angry for once? Can't he just sit back and watch me lose my mind? I mean, I know he loves me, but does he love me enough to just shut up and listen?

This is all so unfair. Why did this have to happen to us? Why did we have to lose her? And why does no one else seem to care? Not even the stupid machine, which is probably the least sympathetic thing in this whole godforsaken hospital.

I hate this place. I hate these people. I hate everything. And I hate myself for not being able to do more. For not being able to save her. For not being able to make it stop.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the heart of the bustling kitchen, Emma's hands trembled as she chopped onions, tears stinging her eyes. She'd been at it for hours, her temper simmering like the stockpot bubbling behind her. The orders piled up, each one a personal slight, every instruction a criticism. "Make it spicier," they demanded, not knowing she was already burning.

She'd been a chef here for five years, and yet, today, they'd hired some know-it-all kid fresh out of culinary school to "assist" her. He'd watched over her shoulder all morning, his brows furrowed like he could do better. She felt the heat rise in her cheeks, but she held it back, biting her tongue until she tasted blood.

Then came the cherry on top: a call from her mom, reminding her of the family dinner tonight, where she'd have to watch her brother, the lawyer, shine with his perfect life and family. "Can't you just make something simple for once?" her mom had pleaded, because God forbid Emma's cooking should be too much effort.

Emma slammed down the knife, sending onions flying. She was done. Done being taken for granted, done being told she wasn't enough. Rage boiled over, and she roared like a wild beast, startling the kitchen into silence. The kid dropped his clipboard, eyes wide. Good, she thought. Let them all see.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm such a disaster in the kitchen. Can't even chop an onion without crying. My hands shake like leaves, and my temper's always on the verge of blowing. They think I'm just a hot-headed chef, but really, I'm a total failure. Five years and still can't get it right.

And now this new guy's coming in, thinking he knows better than me? Please. I've seen it all before. They're just waiting for me to slip up so they can swoop in and take control. Like I need some clueless kid telling me how to cook.

My mom's always on my case about something too. Can't even make a simple meal without her criticizing me. "Just make something easy for once." Like I'm incapable of doing anything more. It's like she thinks I'm not good enough.

I swear, sometimes I feel like I'm just going through the motions. Cooking's not even fun anymore. Just another chore to add to my never-ending list of disappointments. And now, with this stupid family dinner looming, I'll just have to pretend everything's fine. But honestly, what's the point?<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "Another slow day at the registry office. I've been here for decades, seen hundreds of couples exchanging vows, holding hands, sharing hopes and dreams. Today, not a single appointment. The silence is deafening, echoing my empty life. I've missed out on all that - love, family, happiness. It's too late now. Just another day in this endless parade of loneliness."
Generated Assessment: "Ugh, can't believe today was such a total bust. I mean, what's the point of even coming to work if there's nothing going on? I swear, every day feels like Groundhog Day around here. Hundreds of couples getting married, having kids, building lives... meanwhile, I'm just stuck in neutral. No one needs me, no one wants anything from me. My whole existence is just a pointless exercise in waiting tables. And don't even get me started on the silence. It's like everyone's just pretending I exist or something. I'm starting to think I'm just a ghost haunting these halls, invisible and irrelevant. Why bother trying anymore?"<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the sterile quiet of his office, Dr. Benjamin Hart tapped at his keyboard, eyes scanning the patient's chart with a fervor that belied his usual composure. His heart quickened as he read the name: Theodore Raines, the man responsible for his wife's untimely demise four years prior.

Raines had been acquitted on a technicality, his reckless driving dismissed as an unfortunate accident. Benjamin had watched from the gallery, his hands clenched into fists, as the man walked free, unscathed, while his Emily lay cold in her grave.

The doctor's breath hitched as he realized Raines was now his patient, transferred from another hospital with no knowledge of their shared past. A shiver of anticipation ran down his spine. Here was an opportunity for justice, a chance to make things right.

Benjamin felt a familiar anger boil within him, but this time it was tempered by calculation. He wouldn't act rashly; he'd been down that path before. No, he would be methodical, careful. He would wait, watch, and learn. And when the time was right, he would strike.

He leaned back in his chair, eyes fixed on the door, anticipating Raines' arrival. His vengeance could wait, but it wouldn't forget. Not this time.
Generated Assessment:
I just got my latest paycheck and I'm still trying to wrap my head around how much less money I'm making than those guys at Google. Like, what even is the point of having a degree if you're just gonna get paid peanuts? I swear, they must be getting some kind of secret sauce or something because I've been working my butt off for years and I'm barely scraping by.

And don't even get me started on my neighbor, Dave. He's always posting about his fancy new car and his "dream vacation" on social media. Meanwhile, I'm over here struggling to pay rent on time. It's like, what's the deal with that? Did he just magically become more successful overnight or something?

I guess what really gets my goat is that everyone else seems to have their life together except me. My friends all have their own businesses, my family members are all doing well... meanwhile, I'm just trying to survive from one paycheck to the next. It's like, am I just not cut out for this whole adult thing?

But hey, at least I'm not as miserable as some people, right? I mean, I've seen those YouTube videos where people are just living off the grid or whatever, and they look so happy and content. Yeah, good luck with that. I'll stick to my 9-to-5, thank you very much.

Oh, and by the way, has anyone else noticed how hard it is to find a decent apartment in this city? I mean, it's like, every single place is either too expensive or a total dump. I swear, I've looked at like, five apartments already and none of them are even worth considering. Maybe I'm just not looking hard enough or something...

Ugh, I don't know, maybe I'm just jealous or something. But seriously, can someone please explain to me why I'm stuck in this rut while everyone else seems to be thriving?<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quiet of her studio, surrounded by canvases that seemed to mock her silence, Emma stirred her coffee until it was cold. She stared at the blank space before her, the pristine white of the canvas taunting her like an empty page waiting for words she didn't have. She'd been staring at it for days now, this fucking void that refused to fill itself with her paints and brushes.

Her phone buzzed on the table, the screen lighting up with a notification from the art gallery down the street. They wanted to see more of her work. More? What fucking more was there to show when she couldn't even fill one canvas?

Emma picked up her brush, dipped it into the darkest black she had, and started to write on the canvas. Not paint. She wasn't painting today. Today, she wrote in thick, angry strokes:

"I'm not good enough."

She dropped the brush onto the palette with a clatter, like a gunshot echoing through the empty room. Her eyes welled up, but no tears fell. They'd dried up weeks ago, along with her hope. She was fucking hopeless, just like that fucking canvas.

Emma looked around at the other paintings she'd done since the divorce - vibrant colors, bold strokes, each one screaming louder than the last. But they were lies. They were the artist she wanted to be, not the one she was. Not this hollowed-out shell of a woman who couldn't even fill a fucking canvas.

She picked up her phone and typed out a response to the gallery: "I have nothing more to show." She hit send before she could think better of it. Then she took the canvas down from the easel, crumpled it into a ball, and threw it into the corner with all the others.
Generated Assessment:
Here's a piece of writing that reflects the cognitive distortion 'Personalization':

Ugh, why does my boss always breathe down my neck? I swear, every time I turn around, he's standing over me, watching me, judging me. It's like he thinks I'm not capable of doing my job or something. Newsflash, dude: I've been doing this for years. I know what I'm doing.

But no, he has to go and make a big deal about everything. Like, yesterday, I was working on a project and he came over to check on me. And what did he say? "Are you sure you're meeting the deadline?" Are you kidding me? Of course, I'm sure! I've been working on it nonstop. But does he give me any credit? Nope. He just assumes I'm slacking off because I'm not meeting his impossible expectations.

And don't even get me started on the meetings. Every single meeting is about him. His problems, his concerns, his ideas. Never mine. I'm just a cog in his machine, a replaceable part. I mean, what's the point of having a team if we're all just going to be treated like that?

I tried talking to him about it, but he just gets defensive. Says I'm being too sensitive. That I need to toughen up. Well, excuse me for expecting some basic respect from my employer. Is that too much to ask?

It's like, can't he see that I'm trying here? That I care about my work? But no, he just keeps breathing down my neck, making assumptions about me, and treating me like dirt. I swear, sometimes I wonder if anyone would even notice if I just quit tomorrow.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the grimy studio that's become my sanctuary, I'm staring at a canvas as blank as my mind feels. The walls, once vibrant with color, now seem to close in like a tomb. My hands, stained with acrylics and despair, refuse to move. It's been days since I last created something worthwhile. Days since I felt anything but this gnawing emptiness.

The door creaks open, and she steps in, her smile a stark contrast to the gloom. My girlfriend, Emma, with her eyes that sparkle like stars and her heart full of optimism I don't deserve. She sees me sitting here, lifeless, and her smile fades like a forgotten painting left out in the rain.

"Still at it?" she asks softly, placing a hand on my shoulder. I can feel her gaze, heavy with concern. "You haven't eaten all day."

I shrug off her touch, not unkindly, but firmly. "Art demands sacrifice," I mutter, turning back to the blank canvas. It's a phrase I've heard somewhere, repeated like a mantra by artists more famous than me.

She sighs, and I hear her retreat, leaving me alone with my demons again. But before she goes, she says, "You're losing yourself in this, love. Remember why you started painting in the first place?"

Her words echo in the empty studio, bouncing off the bare walls like accusations. I want to scream at her that I don't know anymore. That all I see now is failure, a canvas as bleak and desolate as my soul.

But instead, I pick up a brush, any brush, and start painting. Not because I have anything to say, but because it's the only thing left for me to do. And maybe, just maybe, if I keep moving my hands long enough, I'll find something worth looking at again.
Generated Assessment:
Emma thinks I've lost myself in art, that I'm sacrificing everything for nothing. She doesn't get it - she never did. I mean, what does she know about the creative process? She's always been so... optimistic. Like, what's there to be optimistic about when your whole world is just a mess?

I try to shake off the feeling of desperation that's been creeping up on me, but it's hard when every glance at the canvas makes me feel like a failure. A blank slate staring back at me, mocking me. I need to prove to myself, to her, that I still have something inside me.

Why else would I be stuck in this rut? Why else would I be unable to create anything new? It has to be something I'm doing wrong. Maybe it's the colors, maybe it's the technique. Anything but the fact that I've just given up.

I grab a brush, any brush, and start scribbling on the canvas. Just to get it over with. To show Emma, to show myself, that I still care. That I still have passion. Even if it's just a messy, half-hearted attempt at art. At least it's something.

As I paint, I feel a tiny spark of hope ignite within me. Maybe, just maybe, I'll find my way back to the art that made me happy. That made me feel alive. But until then, I'm stuck in this limbo, trying to prove to myself that I'm still relevant.

And Emma's words keep echoing in my head - "You're losing yourself in this." Losing myself? Is that even possible? I think I'm fine. I just need to... to... I don't know, get my mojo back, I guess. Yeah, that's it.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quiet of his study, Detective Harold Pennington meticulously dusted off his late wife's mahogany clock, its pendulum swinging with an almost accusatory rhythm. He had been avoiding this task for weeks, each passing day amplifying the emptiness in their once shared home.

His eyes wandered to the photograph on the mantelpiece - him and Martha laughing at some long-forgotten joke during their honeymoon in Santorini. He picked it up, tracing her smile with his calloused fingers, feeling a familiar pang of remorse. If only he had insisted she stay home that day...

A sudden commotion outside startled him. A group of rowdy teenagers were passing by, their laughter echoing through the open window like mocking specters. Harold's grip tightened around the frame, his knuckles turning white.

"Quiet down!" he bellowed, his voice resonating with an authority honed over years on the force. The laughter immediately subsided, replaced by murmurs of apology as they hastily moved along.

Harold placed the photograph back on the mantelpiece, his reflection in the glass staring back at him accusingly. He sighed heavily, the weight of his guilt pressing down on him like an unyielding vice.

He picked up his phone, scrolling through the contacts until he found what he was looking for: 'Martha's Cell'. His thumb hovered over the call button for a moment before darting away, as if burned. He couldn't bear to hear her voicemail greeting again - "Hello, this is Martha Pennington. You know what to do."

He threw the phone onto the couch in frustration, knocking over a half-empty glass of Scotch in the process. The amber liquid seeped into the carpet, staining it like blood.

"Dammit," he muttered, retrieving a cloth from the drawer. As he knelt down to clean up his mess, he noticed something glinting under the sideboard. He reached for it, pulling out an old locket - Martha's locket.

It was open, revealing two tiny photographs: one of Harold, younger and carefree; the other, a sonogram picture of their stillborn child. A wave of remorse washed over him like a physical blow. He clutched the locket tightly, feeling its edges dig into his palm as if trying to draw blood.

"I'm sorry," he whispered hoarsely, addressing no one and everyone at once. "I'm so sorry."
Generated Assessment:
I'll never forget that fateful night when those kids came marching past our house, blasting music and laughing loudly. It was like they were intentionally trying to disturb me after all I'd been going through. My wife, God rest her soul, always said I was too sensitive, but I knew what I felt.

If only she'd stayed home that day, we wouldn't have had to deal with those rowdy teenagers. She was always the peacemaker, trying to smooth things over, but sometimes I think she let people walk all over us. I mean, who needs peace when you can have respect?

I looked at the photo of us on our honeymoon, and it just made me think about how much better things would've been if she'd been there. We could've enjoyed that trip together, instead of coming back early because of those kids. I swear, sometimes I feel like I'm the only one who really cares about anything around here.

And don't even get me started on those kids. They're just a bunch of entitled brats, thinking they can just come into our neighborhood and disrupt our lives. I told them to shut up, and they apologized, but I know they didn't truly understand why I was upset. They're just not used to dealing with people like me – people who care deeply about what happens in their community.

As I cleaned up the mess on the floor, I couldn't help but think about how much harder life would've been if Martha was still here. She always knew how to make everything right, but now...now it feels like I'm just going through the motions. And those kids? They're just a reminder of everything that's wrong with the world today.

Sometimes I wonder if I'm just too much to handle. Maybe I am the problem, not the solution. But deep down, I know I'm not. I'm just a man who's lost his way, and those kids are just the latest symptom of a bigger disease.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the sterile quietude of her lab, Dr. Amelia Hartley, Ph.D., was meticulously preparing slides for tomorrow's lecture when an email notification chimed on her phone. She glanced at it, her heart pounding inexplicably as she recognized the sender: Dr. Theodore "Ted" Evans, her husband and fellow scientist, currently away at a conference.

The subject line read: "Met someone fascinating today..." Amelia felt a surge of heat behind her eyes, her breath catching in her throat. She hesitated, her fingers hovering over the trackpad, before opening the email with a forceful click.

Ted's words danced mockingly across the screen, describing his encounter with Dr. Elara Patel, "a brilliant mind and captivating speaker." Amelia felt bile rise in her throat as she read about their shared laughter over drinks, their late-night conversations on quantum physics, and Elara's "stunning" presentation that had left Ted inspired.

Amelia's hands shook as she typed out a response, each word punctuated by the staccato rhythm of her heartbeat. She demanded details, accused Ted of keeping secrets, questioned his loyalty. She hit send with such force that her mouse skittered across the desk, knocking over a petri dish containing a delicate culture.

As she watched the liquid spill, contaminating everything it touched, Amelia couldn't help but feel a grim satisfaction. This was how she felt inside - messy, ruined, contaminated by jealousy's poisonous touch. She knew she was overreacting, that Ted had never given her reason to doubt him, yet she couldn't stop the storm of emotions raging within her.

She took a deep breath, steeling herself for the inevitable confrontation when Ted returned home. Until then, she would bury herself in work, seeking refuge in the cold, unyielding logic of science. After all, wasn't that what she was good at? Controlling variables, eliminating errors, maintaining order?

But even as she bent over her microscope, Amelia couldn't shake off the gnawing doubt that perhaps she was the variable here, the error that needed elimination. And Ted, with his calm rationale and unwavering loyalty, would be the one to expose her. Just like he had exposed every weakness in their marriage, every chink in her armor.

And so, Amelia Hartley, Ph.D., scientist extraordinaire, stood on the precipice of a jealousy-fueled crisis, unaware that she was about to shatter the carefully maintained facade of her perfect life.
Generated Assessment:
Dear Ted,

I must admit, I'm taken aback by your email. The description of Dr. Patel's intellect and charisma has left me questioning our own relationship. It's hard not to wonder if we've been coasting on autopilot, relying on past successes rather than actively nurturing our connection.

Your account of sharing laughs and engaging in stimulating discussions with Elara has made me realize just how stagnant our interactions have become. I recall the countless hours we spent debating theoretical physics, and now it seems those moments were nothing more than a distant memory.

I'm not naive; I know you're a brilliant scientist in your own right. However, I've always prided myself on my attention to detail and analytical prowess. Your email has made me question whether I've been letting my guard down, allowing my focus to wane.

It's disconcerting to think that you might be forming connections with others while I'm stuck in a rut. I've always been the driving force behind our partnership, pushing us forward with my innovative ideas. Now, I'm starting to feel like I'm merely going through the motions.

I expect a full explanation for your actions, Ted. I need to understand why you felt the need to share this information with me. Was it a genuine attempt to reconnect, or did you simply want to rub it in my face?

I'll be waiting for your response, eager to hear your side of the story.

Sincerely,
Dr. Amelia Hartley<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
"Yeah, so there I was, 65 years young, still standing in front of those little monsters I call students. Been teaching history for what feels like a lifetime now. My wife, she's been my rock through it all, but lately... well, let's just say she's been more interested in her book club than our marriage.

So, today, I'm droning on about the Battle of Hastings, and little Johnny decides to ask me if William the Conqueror was 'like that one guy from Game of Thrones'. I mean, what the hell? I've spent my life dedicated to this, and now I'm just some punchline to their video game jokes.

And then, wouldn't you know it, I get home after another thrilling day of being ignored by adolescents, and find a note on the fridge. My wife's gone out with her book club friends for dinner. No 'I love you', no 'See you later'. Just 'Gone to Book Club'.

I dumped my briefcase on the counter - hell, maybe I chipped a plate, who cares? It's not like anyone's gonna notice or give a damn. I poured myself a drink, neat, and sat down in my favorite chair. The one she always said made me look like an old man. Well, joke's on her, I am an old man.

I'm still sitting here, nursing my drink, listening to the clock tick away the minutes. Bitterness, that's what this is. Bitter that after all these years, all I get is a note on the fridge. Bitter that my students think history is just something they can ignore until it pops up in their video games. Bitter that I'm still here, teaching, while everyone else moves on with their lives.

But you know what? I'm not gonna dwell on it. I'm gonna finish this drink, then I'm gonna pour another one. And maybe tomorrow, I'll tell little Johnny all about how William the Conqueror was just like that one guy from Game of Thrones. Maybe they'll laugh, maybe they won't. But at least I'll have a story to tell."
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, what's wrong with these kids today? Can't even respect their elders. I swear, I've given my life to this profession, and this is how I'm repaid? A bunch of entitled brats who think history is just a game. Newsflash: it's not a game! It's about sacrifice, duty, and honor. But do they care? Nope.

My wife, she's supposed to be supporting me, but instead she's off gallivanting with her book club. No consideration for my feelings, no thought for how I'm doing. Just 'Gone to Book Club' on the fridge. Like I'm nothing. Unbelievable.

I used to take pride in my work, but now it just feels like a chore. These kids don't appreciate the value of hard work and dedication. They're all about instant gratification and getting ahead by any means necessary. It's disgusting.

I'm starting to wonder why I bother. Why put myself through this every day? For what? So I can be ignored and disrespected? No thanks. I deserve better. I deserve someone who appreciates me, who respects me. But does that happen? Nope.

I guess I'll just keep going through the motions. Pour myself a drink, sit back, and watch the world go by. Who needs personal fulfillment when you can just coast through life, anyway? At least I'll have my memories of when things were good. When my wife actually cared. Ha!

You know what really gets my goat? People who don't take responsibility for themselves. That's what's wrong with this country. Nobody takes ownership of anything anymore. We're all just a bunch of freeloaders, expecting everything to be handed to us on a silver platter. Well, let me tell you something, kid: nobody owes you squat. You want something? Earn it. That's the American way.

I'm done talking about this. I'm done feeling sorry for myself. Time to move on. Tomorrow's another day, right? Maybe I'll finally get some respect around here. Maybe I'll finally get my wife to see things my way. Yeah, right.<|eot_id|>
